_**Yellowstone**_ is an American [drama](/wiki/Drama_\(film_and_television\)
"Drama \(film and television\)") television series created by [Taylor
Sheridan](/wiki/Taylor_Sheridan "Taylor Sheridan") and [John
Linson](/wiki/John_Linson "John Linson") that premiered on June 20, 2018 on
[Paramount Network](/wiki/Paramount_Network "Paramount Network"). It stars
[Kevin Costner](/wiki/Kevin_Costner "Kevin Costner"), [Wes
Bentley](/wiki/Wes_Bentley "Wes Bentley"), [Kelly Reilly](/wiki/Kelly_Reilly
"Kelly Reilly"), [Luke Grimes](/wiki/Luke_Grimes "Luke Grimes"), [Cole
Hauser](/wiki/Cole_Hauser "Cole Hauser"), [Dave Annable](/wiki/Dave_Annable
"Dave Annable") and [Gil Birmingham](/wiki/Gil_Birmingham "Gil Birmingham").
The series follows the conflicts along the shared borders of a large cattle
ranch, an Indian reservation, land developers and [Yellowstone National
Park](/wiki/Yellowstone_National_Park "Yellowstone National Park"). On July
24, 2018, it was announced that Paramount Network had renewed the series for a
second season to air in 2019.

##
Premise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Premise")]

_Yellowstone_ follows "the Dutton family, led by John Dutton, who controls the
largest contiguous ranch in the United States, under constant attack by those
it borders — land developers, an Indian reservation, and America’s first
National Park. It is an intense study of a violent world far from media
scrutiny — where land grabs make developers billions, and politicians are
bought and sold by the world’s largest oil and lumber corporations. Where
drinking water poisoned by fracking wells and unsolved murders are not news:
they are a consequence of living in the new frontier. It is the best and worst
of America seen through the eyes of a family that represents both."[1]

## Cast and
characters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast and characters")]

###
Main[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Main")]

  * [Kevin Costner](/wiki/Kevin_Costner "Kevin Costner") as John Dutton, the 6th generation patriarch of the Dutton family which controls the largest contiguous ranch in the United States. He is confronted with challenge of defending his land from those who would seek to take it from him while also overcoming the recent death of his son and a recent diagnosis of colon cancer. [Josh Lucas](/wiki/Josh_Lucas "Josh Lucas") portrays a young John Dutton in a recurring role.
  * [Luke Grimes](/wiki/Luke_Grimes "Luke Grimes") as Kayce Dutton, a former US Navy SEAL and one of John and Evelyn's sons. He lives on the local Indian reservation with his wife and son. Rhys Alterman portrays a young Kayce in a recurring role.
  * [Kelly Reilly](/wiki/Kelly_Reilly "Kelly Reilly") as Beth Dutton, a financier and the daughter of John and Evelyn. She is educated, highly intelligent, and a master manipulator. She is also, however, very unstable and suffers from a substance abuse problem. [Kylie Rogers](/wiki/Kylie_Rogers "Kylie Rogers") portrays a young Beth in a recurring role.
  * [Wes Bentley](/wiki/Wes_Bentley "Wes Bentley") as Jamie Dutton, an attorney, aspiring politician, and one of John and Evelyn's sons. Although completely loyal to his father and family, he is constantly frustrated at the current state of his family. He also has an intense love/hate relationship with his sister Beth. Dalton Baker portrays a young Jamie in a recurring role.
  * [Cole Hauser](/wiki/Cole_Hauser "Cole Hauser") as Rip Wheeler, the ranch foreman at Yellowstone and John's right-hand man and enforcer. Rip has worked on the ranch for many years and is fiercely loyal to John. He has an on-again, off-again relationship with Beth. Kyle Red Silverstein portrays a young Rip Wheeler in a guest appearance in the episode "The Unraveling: Pt. 1".
  * [Kelsey Asbille](/wiki/Kelsey_Chow "Kelsey Chow") as Monica Dutton, Kayce's Native American wife with whom he lives on the local reservation. She is a teacher at the school on the local Indian reservation.
  * Brecken Merrill as Tate Dutton, the son of Kayce and Monica and John's only grandchild.
  * Jefferson White as Jimmy Hurdstrom, a ranch hand at Yellowstone.
  * [Danny Huston](/wiki/Danny_Huston "Danny Huston") as Dan Jenkins, a land developer with aspirations of building on parts of Yellowstone.
  * [Gil Birmingham](/wiki/Gil_Birmingham "Gil Birmingham") as Chief Thomas Rainwater, the chief of the nearby Indian reservation.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Development")]

In 2013, [Taylor Sheridan](/wiki/Taylor_Sheridan "Taylor Sheridan") began work
on the series, having recently grown tired of acting and begun writing
screenplays. Having lived in the rural parts of states such as Texas and
Wyoming, Sheridan purposely set the series in Montana and went about writing
the first scripts in [Livingston](/wiki/Livingston,_Montana "Livingston,
Montana").[11]

On May 3, 2017, it was announced that the Paramount Network had greenlit its
first scripted series, _Yellowstone_. Paramount issued a series order for a
first season consisting of ten episodes. The series was set to be written,
directed, and executive-produced by Sheridan. Other executive producers were
to include [John Linson](/wiki/John_Linson "John Linson"), [Art
Linson](/wiki/Art_Linson "Art Linson"), [Harvey
Weinstein](/wiki/Harvey_Weinstein "Harvey Weinstein"), and David Glasser.
Production companies involved with the series were set to consist of Linson
Entertainment and [The Weinstein Company](/wiki/The_Weinstein_Company "The
Weinstein Company").[1]

On October 12, 2017, it was announced that following reports of [sexual abuse
allegations](/wiki/Harvey_Weinstein_sexual_abuse_allegations "Harvey Weinstein
sexual abuse allegations") against producer Harvey Weinstein, his name would
be removed from the series' credits as would The Weinstein Company as
well.[12] On January 15, 2018, Kevin Kay, president of Paramount Network,
clarified during the annual [Television Critics
Association](/wiki/Television_Critics_Association "Television Critics
Association")'s winter press tour that _Yellowstone_ will not have The
Weinstein Company's credits or logo on them, even though that company was
involved in production. Furthermore, he stated that their intent is to replace
Weinstein Television with the company’s new name in the show's credits when
available.[13] That same day, it was also announced that the series would
premiere on June 20, 2018.[14]

On July 24, 2018, it was announced that Paramount Network had renewed the
series for a second season that was expected to premiere in 2019.[15]

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Casting")]

On May 15, 2017, it was announced that [Kevin Costner](/wiki/Kevin_Costner
"Kevin Costner") had been cast in the series lead role of John Dutton.[16] In
June 2017, it was reported that [Luke Grimes](/wiki/Luke_Grimes "Luke
Grimes"), [Cole Hauser](/wiki/Cole_Hauser "Cole Hauser"), [Wes
Bentley](/wiki/Wes_Bentley "Wes Bentley"), and [Kelly
Reilly](/wiki/Kelly_Reilly "Kelly Reilly") had joined the cast as series
regulars.[17][18] On July 13, 2017, it was announced that [Kelsey
Asbille](/wiki/Kelsey_Chow "Kelsey Chow") had been cast in a main role.[19] In
August 2017, it was reported that [Dave Annable](/wiki/Dave_Annable "Dave
Annable"), [Gil Birmingham](/wiki/Gil_Birmingham "Gil Birmingham"), and
Jefferson White had been added to the main cast while [Wendy
Moniz](/wiki/Wendy_Moniz "Wendy Moniz"), [Gretchen Mol](/wiki/Gretchen_Mol
"Gretchen Mol"), [Jill Hennessy](/wiki/Jill_Hennessy "Jill Hennessy"),
[Patrick St. Esprit](/wiki/Patrick_St._Esprit "Patrick St. Esprit"), [Ian
Bohen](/wiki/Ian_Bohen "Ian Bohen"), Denim Richards, and [Golden
Brooks](/wiki/Golden_Brooks "Golden Brooks") were joining the cast in a
recurring capacity.[20][21][22][23] In November 2017, it was announced that
[Michaela Conlin](/wiki/Michaela_Conlin "Michaela Conlin") and [Josh
Lucas](/wiki/Josh_Lucas "Josh Lucas") had been added to the cast in recurring
roles.[24][25] On December 19, 2017, it was reported that [Heather
Hemmens](/wiki/Heather_Hemmens "Heather Hemmens") was joining the cast in a
recurring capacity.[26] On June 13, 2018, it was announced that [Barret
Swatek](/wiki/Barret_Swatek "Barret Swatek") had been cast in a recurring
role.[27]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Filming")]

Principal photography for the series began in August 2017 at the Chief Joseph
Ranch in [Darby, Montana](/wiki/Darby,_Montana "Darby, Montana"), which stands
in as the home of John Dutton. Filming also took place that month near [Park
City, Utah](/wiki/Park_City,_Utah "Park City, Utah"). The production used all
three soundstages at the Utah Film Studio in Park City, which is a total of
45,000 square feet. The building also houses offices, editing, a huge wardrobe
department and construction shops. By November 2017, the series had filmed in
more than twenty locations in Utah, including the Salt Flats and Spanish Fork.
Additionally, filming also took place at various locations in Montana.
Production was reportedly set to last until December 2017.[28][29]

###
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Music")]

The series' score was composed by [Brian Tyler](/wiki/Brian_Tyler "Brian
Tyler") who worked with musicians from the [London Philharmonia
Orchestra](/wiki/London_Philharmonia_Orchestra "London Philharmonia
Orchestra") and viola, cello, and violin soloists. On August 17, 2018, the
soundtrack for the first season was released by [Sony Music](/wiki/Sony_Music
"Sony Music").[30]

Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Release")]

###
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Marketing")]

On February 28, 2018, a teaser trailer for the series was released.[31] On
April 26, 2018, the first full trailer was released.[32]

###
Premiere[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Premiere")]

On June 25, 2018, the series held a screening at Seriesfest, an annual
international television festival, at the Red Rocks Amphitheatre in [Denver,
Colorado](/wiki/Denver,_Colorado "Denver, Colorado").[33][34]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Critical response")]

The series has been met with a mixed response from critics upon its premiere.
On the [review aggregation](/wiki/Review_aggregation "Review aggregation")
website [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the first
season holds a 51% approval rating, with an average rating of 5.86 out of 10
based on 35 reviews. The website's critical consensus reads, "_Yellowstone_
proves too melodramatic to be taken seriously, diminishing the effects of the
talented cast and beautiful backdrops."[35] [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic
"Metacritic"), which uses a weighted average, assigned the season a score of
53 out of 100 based on 26 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews."[36]

###
Ratings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yellowstone_\(U.S._TV_series\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Ratings")]

The two-hour series premiere of _Yellowstone_ averaged 2.8 million viewers in
live + same day and became the most-watched original scripted series telecast
ever on Paramount Network (or its predecessor Spike). The premiere audience
grows to nearly 4 million when the two encore airings of the premiere are
factored in. The premiere audience more than doubled that of Paramount
Network’s first scripted drama series, _[Waco](/wiki/Waco_\(miniseries\) "Waco
\(miniseries\)")_ and more than tripled the debut viewership of Paramount
Network's new comedy series, _[American
Woman](/wiki/American_Woman_\(TV_series\) "American Woman \(TV
series\)")_.[37] It was later reported that the premiere's Live+3 Nielsen
ratings revealed that 4.8 million viewers ultimately watched the premiere
after delayed viewing was factored in.[38] By the series' third episode, it
was reported that the show had become the second most watched television
series on ad-supported cable to air in 2018, only behind
[AMC](/wiki/AMC_\(TV_channel\) "AMC \(TV channel\)")'s _[The Walking
Dead](/wiki/The_Walking_Dead_\(TV_series\) "The Walking Dead \(TV
series\)")_.[39]
